question_details.title: Will Elon Musk's million-dollar giveaway to register voters be considered illegal on December 31, 2025?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2024-11-27 22:32:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/30344). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

This forecasting question is associated with the Verity controversy: [Will Elon Musk's Million-Dollar Giveaway to Registered Voters Be Ruled Illegal?](https://www.verity.news/controversy/Will-Elon-Musks-milliondollar-giveaway-to-register-voters-be-ruled-illegal)

On 19 October 2024, Elon Musk, the tech multi-billionaire and the world’s richest man, announced [he was planning to give away $1 million daily to a swing state voter in the run-up to the United States presidential election on 5 November.](https://www.forbes.com/sites/mollybohannon/2024/10/20/elon-musk-giving-1-million-daily-to-swing-state-voters-who-sign-his-petition-in-latest-controversial-giveaway/) To be eligible for the gift, [voters had to sign a petition created by Musk’s political action committee America PAC and be registered in a swing state.](https://www.vox.com/politics/378912/musk-trump-voting-contest-million-dollars-swing-state-lottery-pennsylvania) According to Musk, the winners were not chosen randomly by a lottery draw but rather [“selected to earn $1m as a spokesperson for America PAC.](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/crlnjzzk919o)" [As GOP lawyer Chris Gober argued](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/politics/musks-pac-claims-1-million-winners-not-chosen-by-chance), “[t]he $1 million recipients are not chosen by chance. We know exactly who will be announced as the $1 million recipient today and tomorrow.” This is a departure from what Musk originally claimed, stating the giveaway was [“going to be award[ed] … randomly to people who have signed the petition”](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/crlnjzzk919o) at a campaign event. 
The giveaway, however, has not been without controversy. After its announcement, Elon Musk and America PAC’s actions came under significant scrutiny. Notably, Josh Shapiro, the Democratic governor of Pennsylvania, described the strategy as [“deeply concerning” and “something that law enforcement could take a look at.”](https://www.politico.com/live-updates/2024/10/20/2024-elections-live-coverage-updates-analysis/elon-musk-money-giveaway-josh-shapiro-00184523) Legal experts have also offered differing opinions on the giveaway’s legality. Richard Hasen, a legal scholar teaching at the University of California, Los Angeles, claimed that the giveaway was [“clearly illegal”](https://x.com/rickhasen/status/1847815868924715295). On the other hand, Bradley Smith, a Professor at Capital University Law School and former Professor at Capital University Law School, argued that whilst he could understand why it could be argued Musk’s tactic has broken the law, ultimately [“the better catch is that it does not."](https://youtu.be/I2eZhYqmP4U?si=XND0WFQdpabyFEjP&t=190) Others still, like Dave Aronberg and Kim Wyman, have stressed that any judgements would be premature, stating that Musk is operating in a [“gray zone”](https://www.newsweek.com/legal-analysts-react-dojs-election-warning-elon-musk-1974003) where [“the answer is not clear”](https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2024/10/24/elon-musk-pay-1-million-daily-voters-trump/75822067007/). 
So far, the giveaway has only resulted in [one lawsuit](https://www.forbes.com/sites/alisondurkee/2024/10/28/philadelphia-da-sues-elon-musks-pro-trump-pac-over-1-million-giveaway/). At the end of October, Philadelphia District Attorney Larry Krasner (a self-described "progressive prosecutor") took Musk and America PAC to court, accusing them of hatching an [“illegal lottery scheme to influence voters in that election.”](https://drive.google.com/file/d/13X8d5QADhuuPghc01ousqJeIzxtLO1kc/view?pli=1) However, after lawyers on behalf of Musk and America PAC revealed the giveaway was not a lottery, [Philadelphia Judge Angelo Foglietta refused to impose an injunction and ruled that the giveaway could continue.](https://www.forbes.com/sites/alisondurkee/2024/11/04/elon-musk-pacs-1-million-giveaways-upheld-in-court/)
Despite this, the opposition to Musk’s actions, and the open debate amongst legal experts about the giveaway’s legality, means that the possibility Musk and America PAC may be brought into court in the future cannot be ruled out, leaving the possibility open as to whether it will be ruled illegal.

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":30344,"question_id":30142}}`
question_details.resolution_criteria: The question will resolve as **Yes** if, on December 31, 2025, Elon Musk’s initiative to offer a million-dollar giveaway to incentivize voter registration has been ruled illegal by any U.S. court or regulatory body and this ruling has not been overturned, according to credible sources.

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Trumpy Billionaire Reveals He Told Musk Not to Give His Fortune to Charity**
According to transcripts and audio of lectures reviewed by Reuters, Peter Thiel, a right-wing billionaire and co-founder of PayPal and Palantir, urged Elon Musk to reconsider his commitment to the Giving Pledge—a philanthropic initiative co-founded by Bill Gates in 2010 that calls for wealthy individuals to donate a significant portion of their wealth to charity. Thiel warned Musk that if he followed through on the pledge, a large portion of his fortune could go to 'left-wing nonprofits' selected by Gates, whom Musk has publicly disagreed with. Thiel cited actuarial data, calculating that if Musk died within the next year, approximately $1.4 billion could be transferred to Gates. Musk reportedly responded, 'What am I supposed to do -- give it to my children?' and added, 'You know, it would be much worse to give it to Bill Gates.' Thiel also expressed apocalyptic concerns, suggesting that a future 'Antichrist' figure could emerge by exploiting global crises like nuclear war, AI, or climate change to seize power and establish a one-world government. He even speculated whether Donald Trump could be that figure, saying, 'Do you think Trump is the Antichrist? I will give you a hearing. And we should consider that.' Thiel, a longtime supporter of Trump, was one of the first major Silicon Valley figures to back him politically. Musk, who became the first person in history to surpass a $500 billion net worth according to Forbes (though it has since dipped below that threshold), continues to make charitable donations through his Musk Foundation. The Daily Beast has reached out to both Musk and Thiel for comment.
Original language: en
Publish date: October 10, 2025 12:32 PM
Source:[The Daily Beast](https://www.thedailybeast.com/trumpy-billionaire-reveals-he-told-musk-not-to-give-his-fortune-to-charity/)

**ЦИК of Kyrgyzstan Warns Against Premature Campaigning Ahead of November 30, 2025 Parliamentary Elections**
The Central Election Commission (ЦИК) of Kyrgyzstan has reiterated the prohibition of premature campaigning ahead of the upcoming parliamentary elections. The early elections for the Jogorku Kenesh are scheduled for November 30, 2025, following the self-dissolution of the parliament. According to ЦИК, it is illegal to conduct charitable activities, distribute gifts, money, or other material benefits, or engage in covert campaigning before the official announcement of results. The law explicitly forbids vote-buying, the use of religious or ethnic slogans, vilifying opponents, and spreading false information; violations may lead to disqualification of candidates. ЦИК emphasized that fair competition and strict adherence to electoral legislation are essential for the legitimacy of the elections. The elections will be held under a majoritarian system across 30 multi-member constituencies, electing 90 deputies (three per constituency), with one seat reserved for a woman. Candidates may run either through political parties or as independents. As of October 1, 2025, 4.287 million voters are registered in the country. Preliminary voter lists will be published on the official portal www.tizme.gov.kg on October 8 and posted at polling stations on October 14. Voters can verify their registration online, via phone (1255), SMS to 119, or in person at the polling station. Campaigning will officially begin on November 10 and end one day before voting, at 8:00 a.m. on November 29. Voter applications for voting outside polling stations will be accepted until November 28. Election results will be finalized and officially announced by December 14.

**Tucker Carlson: Americans 'marinate in lies' from Israel's 'incredibly sophisticated propaganda' - LifeSite**
Tucker Carlson delivered a highly critical monologue on October 9, 2025, accusing the U.S.-Israel relationship of being a 'poisonous' and 'client-state' dynamic that has led to decades of American political and media complicity in what he describes as Israel’s 'incredibly sophisticated propaganda.' He argues that the U.S. has been 'humiliated' and 'ordered around' by a 'tiny' nation—Israel, with only nine million people and no meaningful natural resources—despite being the largest recipient of U.S. aid in history, with over $300 billion in aid over 80 years, including $30 billion since October 7, 2023. Carlson claims that Americans are 'marinating in lies' due to systemic censorship and intimidation, with dissenters labeled 'Nazis' or 'antisemites' to silence debate. He criticizes Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for interfering in U.S. politics, including pressuring Elon Musk to censor speech on X (Twitter), and for promoting the purchase of TikTok by Zionist billionaires to control American discourse. Carlson calls for restoring U.S. self-respect by ending dependency on Israel, banning dual citizenship, revoking citizenship for Americans fighting for foreign militaries (including in Israel and Ukraine), registering AIPAC under the Foreign Agent Registration Act (FARA), and rejecting Christian Zionism as heresy. He asserts that supporting Israel's actions in Gaza—described as a 'massive displacement and killing of unarmed civilians'—violates Christian doctrine, which prohibits the killing of the innocent. According to Carlson, the 'true chosen people' in Christianity are those who choose Jesus, not those by 'DNA,' and any attempt to justify violence in Israel’s name through religious doctrine is heresy.

**Musk's Boasts About Drugs and State Secrets Backfire Spectacularly**
Elon Musk faced a significant legal setback when U.S. District Judge Denise Cote ruled that his public disclosures on social media—particularly regarding his top-secret security clearance, drug testing, and communications with foreign leaders—waived his right to privacy under the Freedom of Information Act. Cote rejected the Department of Defense’s claim that releasing Musk’s security clearance details would invade his privacy, citing three specific X (formerly Twitter) posts: one from February 2024 stating he had held a top-secret clearance for years, a 2022 post claiming a single conversation with Vladimir Putin about space, and a January 2024 post confirming he agreed to three years of random drug testing at NASA’s request. The judge noted these posts had collectively been viewed over 2 million times, with one reaching 24 million views, establishing that Musk’s public statements outweighed any privacy interest. She ordered the Department of Defense to release the documents, though granted the Trump administration until October 17 to propose redactions. This ruling came amid other legal challenges, including a federal judge denying Musk’s attempt to move an SEC lawsuit over his delayed disclosure of a five-percent stake in Twitter—alleged to have enabled purchases of over $500 million in undervalued shares. Musk, who ended his status as a special government employee in late May 2025, had previously clashed publicly with President Trump, including a controversial post linking Trump’s name to the 'Epstein files,' which Musk later deleted after admitting he had 'gone too far.'

**Elon Musk: From the Richest Man on Earth to a Poverty Testimony of Our Modern Society**
Elon Musk, who is approaching a net worth of 500 billion dollars and is recognized by Forbes as the richest person on Earth—approximately 150 billion dollars ahead of Larry Ellison—has become a symbol of systemic contradictions in modern capitalism. While his entrepreneurial achievements with Tesla and SpaceX are acknowledged as transformative and the result of intense effort and strategic planning, the article criticizes Musk for his controversial political affiliations, including public admiration for Donald Trump and perceived alignment with right-wing populist movements like the AfD. The author argues that Musk’s immense wealth—enough to erase the debt of entire nations—exposes a broken economic system, especially as millions struggle with basic expenses like electricity bills. The piece contends that Musk’s rise is not a triumph of merit but a societal failure: a man with questionable character and conduct has amassed unprecedented power, and the public may ultimately bear the cost of his 'delusional visions.' The article concludes that Musk’s status as the world’s richest person is not a cause for celebration but an indictment of contemporary society. The commentary is published by news.de, with the author Mia Lada-Klein, and was released on October 7, 2025.

**What Do Nobel Peace Prize Winners Do with the Money? Insights from Past Laureates and Trump's Controversial Candidacy**
The 2025 Nobel Peace Prize, worth 11 million Swedish kronor (approximately 967,000 euros), is set to be awarded on October 10, 2025, by the Norwegian Nobel Committee in Oslo. A total of 244 individuals and 94 organizations were nominated. Donald Trump has been publicly advocated for by Israeli President Isaac Herzog, who claimed Trump 'deserves' the prize due to his efforts in Gaza ceasefire negotiations, though bookmakers assign him low chances of winning. The prize money is not directed by the Nobel Foundation; recipients are free to use it as they see fit. Historically, Peace Prize laureates often donate their winnings to humanitarian causes: Juan Manuel Santos (2016) gave his entire prize to victims of Colombia’s civil war; Barack Obama (2009) distributed funds to war veterans, earthquake victims, and impoverished students; and Dmitry Muratov (2022) auctioned his medal for over 100 million USD, with proceeds going to Ukrainian refugee children via UNICEF. Other laureates have used the money for research (Marie Curie, Swetlana Alexijewitsch), investments (Al Gore), or personal purchases (Paul Nurse’s motorcycle, Franco Modigliani’s yacht). Notably, Albert Einstein promised his future Nobel Prize money to his first wife, Mileva, in his 1919 divorce papers, and reportedly fulfilled the promise. In contrast, Trump has shown no indication of charitable intent—refusing to place gifts like a state aircraft from Qatar into public ownership—raising doubts about his potential use of the prize if awarded. The decision will be announced at 11:00 AM Oslo time on October 10.

**Voters sue Elon Musk, say they were defrauded by $1M petition giveaway**
A federal judge has ordered Elon Musk to face a proposed class‑action lawsuit from voters who claim they were misled into signing a petition in the run‑up to the 2024 election by promises of a chance to win $1 million in a daily giveaway. The lawsuit, filed in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas, invokes the Class Action Fairness Act and alleges that the total value of all class members’ claims exceeds $5 million. It seeks damages and injunctive relief on behalf of petition signers who say they were wrongly induced to provide personal identifying information when signing the petition. The complaint names Arizona resident Jacqueline McAferty as lead plaintiff and alleges that America PAC and Musk induced voters in seven battleground states—Pennsylvania, Georgia, Nevada, Arizona, Michigan, Wisconsin and North Carolina—to sign a petition supporting free speech and Second Amendment positions by promising $1 million daily prizes chosen ‘randomly’ until Election Day. The suit says petition signers were required to provide names, addresses, emails and phone numbers and that the defendants benefited by driving traffic to X, Musk’s social platform, and by collecting valuable political contact data. It also alleges that the lottery was not random, giving voters no real chance to collect. In November, Musk’s lawyers told a Pennsylvania judge that winners were not chosen at random but were selected in advance—contradicting Musk’s own statements when he launched the contest. U.S. District Judge Robert Pitman ruled that McAferty plausibly alleged that she had been misled and that an expert could testify about the commercial value of battleground voters’ contact information. Pitman told Reuters on Wednesday: ‘It is plausible that plaintiff justifiably relied on those statements to believe that defendants were objectively offering her the chance to enter a random lottery – even if that is not what they subjectively intended to do.’ Jarrett L. Ellzey of EKSM LLP told Newsweek: ‘We are pleased with the Court’s ruling and agree with Judge Pitman’s careful reasoning. This decision affirms that our client and the proposed class have viable claims and deserve the opportunity to pursue justice.’ Elon Musk said at a Trump campaign event in Pennsylvania on October 19: ‘We are going to be awarding $1 million randomly to people who have signed the petition, every day, from now until the election.’ Christopher Peterson, a University of Utah law professor, told NBC News on November 5, 2024: ‘You cannot lawfully lie to the public about conducting a random sweepstakes, lottery, or contest and then rig the results to hand‑select the winners. It really is not complicated. This is just fraud; a simple, ugly fraud on the public.’ The case, McAferty v. Musk et al., remains before the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas. Pitman has denied dismissal, allowing discovery and further proceedings to go forward.

**Elon Musk Faces Lawsuit Over 'Daily Million Dollar Election Giveaway'**
Elon Musk's 'Daily Million Dollar Election Giveaway' in 2024 was a short-lived sensation, but it soon faced a collective lawsuit from some voters. The voters filed a lawsuit on November 5, 2024, alleging that Musk used a petition to sign in support of the US Constitution as a way to lure them into participating in the daily $1 million giveaway, which involved fraudulent behavior. Musk requested a judge to dismiss the lawsuit in January, stating that he had not organized an 'illegal' giveaway. However, a US federal judge ruled on August 20 that Musk must face the voters' legal challenge. US District Judge Robert Pitman stated in the ruling that Arizona voter Jacqueline McAferty had reasonably alleged that Musk and 'America PAC' misled her into providing personal information to participate in the giveaway by signing a petition in support of the US Constitution. McAferty alleged that Musk and America PAC lured seven swing state voters into signing the petition, promising to randomly select a daily $1 million winner, but the voters had no real chance of winning. She stated that the voters who signed the petition were asked to provide their name, address, email address, and phone number. Musk stated in January that the daily $1 million winner was 'selected to earn' the money, and the organizers of the activity had informed the voters that they would be reviewed to see if they could become a spokesperson for America PAC and earn $1 million. Therefore, he did not believe that the money was a prize. However, the judge pointed out that the plaintiff's statements showed that the defendants had 'awarded' $1 million, and that the money could be 'won.' The ruling stated: 'The plaintiff has a reasonable basis to rely on these statements, believing that the defendant objectively provided her with the opportunity to participate in a random draw -- even if the defendant subjectively did not intend to do so.' Regarding Musk's denial of the voters' claim that they were harmed by providing contact information. Judge Pitman stated that a political data intermediary expert could testify that the information was valuable to swing state voters. Musk and America PAC's lawyers have not commented on the latest ruling. This case is 'McAferty v. Musk,' US District Court for the Western District of Texas, Case No. 24-01346. In the day before the election, a Philadelphia judge refused to stop Musk's giveaway, citing that the city's district attorney had failed to prove that it was an illegal lottery.

Source:[ZEIT ONLINE](https://www.zeit.de/politik/ausland/2025-08/elon-musk-betrugsvorwuerfe-usa-wahlkampf)
summary: Forecasters broadly agree that by December 31, 2025, it is unlikely that Elon Musk’s million-dollar voter registration giveaway will be definitively ruled illegal by a U.S. court or regulatory body with no overturn or stay in effect. While there is significant ongoing litigation—including a federal class action allowed to proceed, and mounting political and media pressure—the process of achieving a final, standing ruling is slow, especially in a high-profile, legally ambiguous case. Most experts point to relevant U.S. election statutes that prohibit giving something of value for voting or registration and acknowledge plausible legal jeopardy. However, the status quo is that no court has made a final adverse ruling, and base rates for similar high-profile campaign incentives being ruled definitively illegal within a year are low. Legal standards are contested, and the evolving justifications for the giveaway (random lottery versus spokesperson selection) muddy the waters further. Even if an adverse lower court ruling occurs before December 31, 2025, appeals or stays are likely, and the question’s resolution criteria require that such a decision not be overturned. Expert forecasts for a 'Yes' outcome (illegality ruled and not overturned) range from 12% to 35%, with most clustering in the 12%–23% range. The consensus is that litigation will likely continue into 2026 or later, with no final, unoverturned finding of illegality by the cutoff date.
